body: Yes, I think it should be feasible! We have plenty of "good" bugs (we can just use past RESOLVED FIXED bugs as examples of "good" bugs), and we can get "bad" bugs by using "Invalid Bugs::General" (hoping there are enough to train the model).
This shouldn't be very tough to implement. @marco-c Please let me know if I should go ahead with this. (I noticed the good-first-bug label, so maybe I should let someone else work on this?)
@marco-c I'm interested in working on this if no one is assigned to it

@ayush-1506 you can work on it, don't worry (I mark them as good-first-issues because they can be worked on in isolation, but it doesn't mean only newcomers can work on them).

@m-agboola you can work on it too, any issue is unassigned until there is a PR open to fix it. It is not the simplest issue though, you might want to start with another one.
Thanks @marco-c I understand and would give it a try!

@marco-c Correct me if I'm wrong:
Good bugs are the ones with `STATUS` as `FIXED` or `RESOLVED`.
Bad bugs are the ones where `Invalid Bugs` was added at any time in the history, right?

If so, there aren't a lot of bad bugs. Maybe we should consider other indicative fields too?

I think the problem is simply that we are not downloading the bad bugs in our DB, as "Invalid Bugs" is not in the list of considered products at https://github.com/mozilla/bugbug/blob/a36edbbe14bd1590d42ac5b171a17c894c066301/bugbug/bugzilla.py#L25.

@marco-c So we'd need to add it to the products, regenerate the bugs db and upload it to tc, right? Should this be a two step PR? (First one adding the label to the products and the second one implementing the model)

It can be a two step PR or a single PR with two separate commits.
Note: you can add new bugs to the DB locally, by simply running the bug_retriever script, so you can start working on the model directly without waiting on the next release for TC to do it.

repository.name: bugbug
repository.description: Platform for Machine Learning projects on Software Engineering
